know_passage: The 117th Senate (2021–2023) is composed of 50 Republicans, 48 Democrats, and 2 Independents who caucus with the Democrats, making the Senate split evenly in terms of broad politics. The filibuster complicates the legislative process, allowing obstruction. The tiebreaker is Vice President Kamala Harris, a Democrat. [27] [28] [29]

know_passage: Between 1917 and 1995, half of the 30 bills killed in the Senate, despite support from majorities in the House and Senate and White House support, were minority rights protections, including those to ban poll taxes, employment and housing discrimination, and lynching. Filibuster reform remains crucial to overcoming legislative gridlock.

know_passage: One estimate predicts that by 2040, about 30% of the American population will live in 35 states represented by 70 senators, while about 70% of the population will live in 15 states represented by 30 senators. That 30% will be older, less racially diverse, and more rural than the majority of the country. Therefore, without necessary filibuster reform, the possibility of a stark minority of senators filibustering and killing legislation supported by the majority of the country only stands to grow worse. This inefficiency undermines legislative progress and exacerbates political tensions.

know_passage: For example, the American Clean Energy and Security Act passed the House but was never brought up in the Senate for certainty the bill would be quashed by filibuster. This highlights the filibuster's detrimental impact on minority rights. The act “would have set new renewable fuel standards and established a cap-and-trade system for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.” [45]
